results.title: Rev
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and colour and audio
results.brief_description: This painterly observation of pedestrian traffic through a revolving door finds a counterpoint in the flickering of a candle flame. As separate lives are blurred with the energy of constant movement, individuals merge into an abstracted urban sound and light space.
results.description: This painterly observation of pedestrian traffic through a revolving door finds a counterpoint in the flickering of a candle flame. As separate lives are blurred with the energy of constant movement, individuals merge into an abstracted urban sound and light space.

results.title: A Scary Time
results.creator_credit: Robert Hughes, Shirley Clarke, Thorold Dickinson and UNICEF
results.brief_description: A powerful emotional plea by the United Nation’s Children Fund, appealing for support from affluent nations using experimental film techniques combining found and improvised footage. The film intercuts footage of American children during their Halloween ‘Trick or Treat’ rounds collecting money for UNICEF with footage of international child hunger. Deals convincingly with the realities of children’s lives in less affluent countries. Music by Peggy Glanville-Hicks.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Hughes, Shirley Clarke, Thorold Dickinson and UNICEF

results.title: Sculpture
results.brief_description: Designed to show the power and beauty of some of Melbourne’s many sculptures from Dante in the Treasury Gardens to the striking figures of St George and the Dragon, and Joan of Arc in front of the State Library of Victoria. The effective soundtrack was arranged and played by Lenore Somerset.

results.title: Safe loads
results.creator_credit: Max Pepper, Peter Dimond, South Australian Film Corporation and Pepper Audio Visual
results.brief_description:
This 1977 film demonstrates the importance of carrying a load safely on a truck. It details the necessary preparation for a drive, including the kind of load being carried, the stacking, placement and securing of the load. It includes a cameo appearance by American pro golfer Johnny Miller at the beginning, and a narrator speaking directly to the camera. Acknowledging that workers often find instructional videos condescending, the narrator speaks in a casual and familiar tone to appeal to the audience. He discusses the danger of petroleum and corrosive acids carried in tankers and the importance of stacking and securing a load correctly. The film ends with a dramatic re-enactment of experienced, yet careless, workers who secure a dangerous load onto a truck, which eventually explodes.

Produced for Mayne Nickless Limited by the South Australian Film Corporation and Pepper Audio Visual.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Cast: Johnny Miller, Roger Ward, Dave Taylor, Robyn Hamilton, Richard Pepper, Ian Gray, David Hursthouse

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Safety in the slaughterhouse
results.creator_credit: John Bowen, Peter Johnson and Camfilm Productions
results.brief_description:
This 1979 film is directed at meat inspectors working in abbatoirs. The film contains footage of workers in abbatoirs and close-ups of inspectors working on carcasses. It includes interviews with three inspectors about the accidents they suffered during their work and a discussion at the pub between a group of meat inspectors on the problems they encounter in their work and the safety precautions they should note.

Produced by Camfilm Productions for the Department of Primary Industry.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Les LeVeque videoworks. Volume 2 (1999 - 2000)
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

group_works.title: 2 Spellbound
group_works.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio

results.title: 4 Vertigo
results.brief_description:
Les LeVeque is a New York-based artist who has produced a number of videos and video installations exploring the cultural implications of technological change. Recently he has been making video works that use Hollywood classics as their starting point, transforming them into sensuous, hallucinatory works which aim to unveil the repressed representations that loiter inside so many ‘wholesome’ American classics. These include ‘2 Spellbound’ (1999), a reworking of Alfred Hitchcock’s ‘Spellbound’ (1945), and ‘Backwards Birth of a Nation’ (2000), in which D.W. Griffith’s 1915 feature film is reversed and re-edited into a 13-minute phantasm. LeVeque’s works have featured at the New York Video Festival, the Sundance Film Festival, the 2000 Whitney Biennial and the Pompidou Centre in Paris.

In ‘4 Vertigo’, Hitchcock’s 128-minute feature film ‘Vertigo’ has been processed anew by capturing one frame for every two seconds of the original movie. The condensed film was duplicated four times, shifting the horizontal or vertical orientation of the frame with each duplication so that the first image is right side up, the next is sideways, then upside down, then sideways, and finally right side up again. This is only evident when the video is examined frame by frame: played at normal speed the result is a stuttering kaleidoscopic engine that gives the viewer a nauseating yet thrilling sensation of physical and psychic
weightlessness. In LeVeque’s treatment the layered plot line and psychological depths of the Hitchcock original are overtaken by the patterns and rhythms of the new aesthetic centrifuge.

LeVeque states: ‘Building on the notion of obsessive looking, I wanted to transform the original movie into a spinning mandala to generate a sensuous viewing where the dramatic narrative becomes unstable and elusive, a viewing experience where the hypnosis of cinematic spectacle is articulated to such a physical degree that it engenders a consciousness of watching.’

results.title: 2 Spellbound
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio
results.brief_description: Les Leveque takes Alfred Hitchcock’s classic psychoanalysis and memory loss thriller and injects it with a large dose of adrenalin. What remains is a speeded up frenzy of image, light and hardcore techno music as Ingrid Bergman and Gregory Peck flash before our eyes, subverting our own memory of the film into a hazy waking dream.

results.title: Planning a city
results.brief_description: Sydney, the second greatest white city in the British Empire. A critical analysis of Sydney and the initial lack of city planning. Despite the surrounding beauty and the opportunity for wise planning, Sydney became a crowded and poorly serviced city. Many houses were built on narrow, cramped and dimly lit streets which contributed to the escalation of crime and disease. Those responsible for constructing roadways rarely considered the impact on residents. Many schools and shopping centres were built on major thoroughfares resulting in a high rate of school children and housewives being killed by cars. Considering the harbourside location, many of the views became obstructed by buildings housing the privileged. The ‘Town and Country Planning Act of 1945’ was introduced to provide an opportunity to remedy the mistakes of the past by planning for future improvements. This film includes scenes of Sydney as it was in the middle of this century and what is now historical footage of cars, buses, trams, trains, ferries and horse and carts.
